Document 178: adjust the system to take into account spike demands, increasing demand 
trends and conversely, decreasing demand trends.
The best systems are systems where signals are not lost, misunderstood or 
misinterpreted.  That is why Kanban systems are so appealing.  The loss of 
dexterity in manual systems only requires one person to be distracted, one 
card to be misplaced or turnover of a key individual to create a hole in the 
process.  Systems that have a great deal of human interaction such as 
manual kanban systems require a stringent system of checks and balances 
to ensure that communication is always taking place.
We can point to a wealth of case studies that demonstrate the value of 
eKanban systems. They reduce inventory which can lead to significant cost

Document 182: information.  These types of adjustments can create great variation throughout 
the supply chain when made simultaneously, or when a slight delay in one area 
has the effect of a greater delay in a later step.  
An eKanban system sending real-time demand signals and providing 
continuous status updates that are visible throughout the plant, can greatly 
reduce the need for physical interactions and ultimately, variability. 
Building Trust in the System
eKanbans can serve to create one source of truth throughout the system.  As 
eKanban signaling is utilized, the amount of variability throughout the process is 
reduced and each step begins to trust the previous step.  This reduces the need 
to add extra protection everywhere in the supply chain.  eKanban

Document 179: to ensure that communication is always taking place.
We can point to a wealth of case studies that demonstrate the value of 
eKanban systems. They reduce inventory which can lead to significant cost 
savings; they shorten lead times, purchase order cycles and more. A hidden 
and often untold benefit, however, is an elevated level of communication 
across the plant floor. And while the capabilities of eKanban software 
packages differ, consider the value of those that provide instantaneous 
demand signals across the organization and extended supply chain – signals 
that are visible and can be tracked by all. Everyone is on the same page, 
even suppliers who have a portal into the system that empowers them to 
replenish items based on the parameters you have set.

Document 127: Copyright ©2017 McGraw -Hill Education. All rights reserved.The Bullwhip Effect
•Bullwhip effect : phenomenon of variability magnification 
as we move from the customer to the producer in the 
supply chain
•A slight change in consumer sales ripples backward as magnified 
oscillations upstream, like the result of a flick of a bullwhip handle
•Forward buying: retailers responding to a temporary 
price cut by stocking up
•Continuous replenishment : inventory is replaced 
frequently, as part of an ongoing process

Document 259: 11
After the BOM information is accessed, the next information the MRP system 
requires to complete the planning job is the inventory records. 
There are two types of inventory records for this discussion: on -hand 
inventory and on -order inventory.
The importance of data accuracy becomes more critical due to data 
dependency. The BOM records must be impeccable and inventory records 
must be pristine. 
Minimally acceptable thresholds for this accuracy require BOM accuracy to be 
at 98%. This means that 98% of the BOMs are perfect.

Document 260: 12
The inputs to MRP (the master schedule, BOM, lead times, purchasing, and 
inventory) frequently change. These frequent changes generate what is called 
system nervousness and can create havoc in purchasing and production 
departments if implemented. OM personnel reduce such nervousness by 
evaluating the need and impact of changes prior to disseminating requests to 
other departments by using two tools: Time fences & Pegging . 
Time fences allow a segment of the master schedule to be designated as “not 
to be rescheduled.”
Pegging means tracing upward in the BOM from the component to the parent 
item. By pegging upward, the production planner can determine the cause for 
the requirement and make a judgment about the necessity for a change in the 
schedule.

Document 68: Copyright ©2017 McGraw- Hill Education. All rights reserved.Buffering, Blocking, and Starving
•Buffer : a storage area between stages where the output 
of a stage is placed prior to being used in a downstream 
stage
•Blocking: occurs when the activities in a stage must stop because there is no place to deposit the item
•Starving: occurs when the activities in a stage must stop because there is no work
•Bottleneck: stage that limits the capacity of the process  
11-14

5
Customer Order-Driven, Pull-Based Kanban 
Systems
Pull-based systems represent the other end of the spectrum. Pull systems 
are based on the Toyota Production System (TPS) and its western 
interpretation, “Lean Manufacturing”. The Pull method from TPS is often 
referred to as a Kanban system – a method for planning, execution and 
inventory replenishment that enables flow through greater control.

Document 157: planning and execution that is pushed out from the top.  Plan results are 
adjusted and reported back up the chain. This slow and often arduous 
feedback loop doesn’t offer much flexibility to quickly respond to the inevitable 
variation in customer demand and execution to the plan. Rather, it often leads 
to a negative spiral of adding inventory, clogging up production and leading to 
diminished capacity and loss of control.  This is the very opposite of what we 
are trying to achieve with our systems.

Document 149: Pull/Kanban systems are driven from a high-level perspective that focuses on 
capacity and material planning based on actual customer demand. The 
assumption for planning here is that the design of the system is balanced 
according to the demands placed on the company.  
So while Push-based systems are front-loaded in planning and rigid in 
execution, Pull-based systems focus on the execution of the customer order 
and are designed to be agile enough to respond quickly to changes in 
demand. Next, we 'll review both systems in greater detail.
Planning in a Push environment is most often executed from an MRP or ERP 
system and starts when senior management sets the near-term and long-term 
financial goals for the company. These goals create the foundation for the

Document 203: 11CONWIP Vs Pure Push System:
CONWIP exhibits the following advantages over a pure 
push system:
•The WIP level is directly observable, while the release rate in a 
push system must be set with respect to (unobservable) capacity.
•It requires less WIP on average to attain the same throughput.
•It facilitates working ahead of a schedule when favorable 
circumstances permit it.
Copyright © 2008 by Wallace J. Hopp and Mark C. Spearman

Document 209: 17Summary
•Push systems schedule the release of work on the basis of 
demand information, while pull systems authorize the release 
of work on the basis of inventory status within the system.
•The “magic” of pull systems is that they establish a WIP cap, which prevents producing unnecessary WIP that does not 
signiﬁcantly improve throughput.
•The simplest mechanism for establishing a WIP cap is 
CONWIP (constant work in process), in which the WIP level 
in a line is held constant by synchronizing releases to departures.
Copyright © 2008 by Wallace J. Hopp and Mark C. Spearman

Document 146: in an organization.
Push v. Pull Planning and Execution Systems     
in Manufacturing
The contrast between Push and Pull-based systems starts at the planning 
phase. In traditional Push-based MRP/ERP environments, a plan is developed 
and pushed through the system. The assumption for planning in a Push 
environment is that everything remains constant; the company has the 
capacity on hand, along with the inventory and decision support staff to 
execute the plan. And while seemingly proactive, the plan often becomes 
obsolete before it is executed as it cannot easily accommodate changes in 
market conditions or adjust to variations inherent in manufacturing 
environments.  manufacturing so ftware
TM

1 |   Push v Pull Planning and 
         Execution Systems in

Document 145: Introduction
This is the first in a series of papers exploring the nature of Pull-based 
manufacturing systems and specifically, Kanban systems. The focus of this 
paper is at the system, or workflow level, while subsequent publications will 
review Pull/Kanban systems from a management, customer and competitive 
standpoint. After reading this paper, you will have a good understanding of 
both Pull and Push-based manufacturing systems and your choices for 
systems within a Pull environment. After reading the collection of papers, you 
should have a 360-degree perspective of the impact of a Pull/Kanban system 
in an organization.
Push v. Pull Planning and Execution Systems     
in Manufacturing
The contrast between Push and Pull-based systems starts at the planning

Document 266: 18
Overlapping is a method that processes part of the lot on the work center 
performing the second operation, while the rest of the lot is still in the work 
center in the first operation. Overlapping reduces lead time in a way similar to 
parallel processing.
Operations Splitting: Throughput time decreases as only part of the lot is 
processed on one machine. 
Lot Splitting /Order Splitting: A lot (or order) is split, and a part of it is run 
ahead of schedule in a period where there is available capacity.

Document 148: production while effectively managing the inevitable constraints. Legacy ERP 
and Push-based MRP systems are hard-pressed to support the Lean and 
demand-driven Pull-based production environments of today. And while Pull-
based systems are more and more becoming a way to bridge the old and the 
new, they require a shift in philosophy as well as a shift in IT systems. Flexible, 
plug-in solutions like Kanban systems, however, are a seemingly efficient (and 
non-disruptive) way to bridge the gap for those looking to gain greater 
control by implementing or expanding upon Lean principles.

Systems
Pull-based systems represent the other end of the spectrum. Pull systems 
are based on the Toyota Production System (TPS) and its western 
interpretation, “Lean Manufacturing”. The Pull method from TPS is often 
referred to as a Kanban system – a method for planning, execution and

Document 187: offer control and predictability while fostering a culture of moving from supply 
chain and manufacturing management working in the system to a mode of 
working on the system.
In this paper, we have explored the nature of Push and Pull systems and more 
specifically, manual and eKanban systems within a Pull environment. In our 
next paper in this series, we will explore Pull/Kanban systems from a 
management perspective, exploring the benefits of a more predictable 
environment along with the decision-making power gained through a deeper 
access to data and analytics.

savings; they shorten lead times, purchase order cycles and more. A hidden 
and often untold benefit, however, is an elevated level of communication 
across the plant floor. And while the capabilities of eKanban software 
packages differ, consider the value of those that provide instantaneous 
demand signals across the organization and extended supply chain – signals 
that are visible and can be tracked by all. Everyone is on the same page, 
even suppliers who have a portal into the system that empowers them to 
replenish items based on the parameters you have set.

Document 183: reduced and each step begins to trust the previous step.  This reduces the need 
to add extra protection everywhere in the supply chain.  eKanban  
communication eliminates the noise of the previous Push signals in the supply  
chain.   
eKanban communications also build trust among suppliers.  In a Push 
environment, there are countless and continuous calls to suppliers to move up 
orders, move out orders, combine orders and to “really, really please” expedite 
deliveries – only to call back later and cancel the order.  Understandably, at 
some point, the validity of these requests may be questioned.  When 
communication is fluid and transparent through the use of an eKanban system,  
interactions with suppliers can turn into more positive and collaborative

1. Single routing
2. WIP measured in units
Mechanics: allow next job to enter line each time a job leaves 
(i.e., maintain a WIP level of m jobs in the line at all times).
Modeling:
•MRP looks like an open queueing  network
•CONWIP looks like a closed queueing network
•Kanban looks like a closed queueing network with blocking. . .

Document 167: second guessing of what is a real change versus changes that are just noise. In 
Pull environments, communication of the change is clear, precise and quickly 
acted upon.
In Lean Manufacturing, there are many tools that are part of a Lean journey. A 
Kanban system is one such tool that represents a visual and functional step in 
the transition from Push to Pull processing.  While there are Kanban systems 
for a variety of purposes (software development, project management, even 
personal productivity Kanbans), in the manufacturing world, we make the 
distinction between manual and electronic – or eKanban software systems.

Document 170: • Between the purchasing organization and suppliers where there are  
mixed methods (e.g., some products are utilizing Push forecasts while  
other products are using Kanban signals).
•• When parts pass between multiple divisions or locations.
Many times, a Kanban system is implemented manually to start. This can help 
ease the organizational transition to the Pull signaling method for more change-
resistant environments and provides the opportunity to implement Kanban as a 
pilot program to test the process and work out the issues.  Usually simple 
processes are used in this approach.  And, like all new processes, there are 
valuable lessons to be learned ::
•• How to size the K-Loops (number of Kanbans in the process).
• How to use Spike Kanban Cards when demand increases.

Document 171: valuable lessons to be learned ::
•• How to size the K-Loops (number of Kanbans in the process).
• How to use Spike Kanban Cards when demand increases.
(A Spike Card is used to quickly increase inventory to account for  
sudden and temporary increases in demand.)
•• When to remove Kanban Cards as demand trends downward.
•• Identifying data that is important for monitoring line performance.
•• Understanding how changes in supplier performance and lead-times
impact K-Loop sizing.
For some, however, the immediate benefits of an eKanban system far outweigh 
the choice for implementing manually first, then transitioning to an electronic 
system. Next, we will take a closer look at eKanban software systems.

Document 109: Copyright ©2017 McGraw -Hill Education. All rights reserved.Example 11.3: A Restaurant
•Consider the restaurant in the casino
•Managers have set up a buffet arrangement where customers 
serve themselves
•Buffet is continually replenished to keep items fresh
•To further speed service a fixed amount is charged for the meal
•Customers take an average of 30 minutes to get their food and 
eat
•They typically eat in groups (or customer parties) of two or three to a table
•The restaurant has 40 tables
•Each table can accommodate four people
•What is the maximum capacity of this restaurant?
11-10

Document 112: Copyright ©2017 McGraw -Hill Education. All rights reserved.Example 11.3: Restaurant Continued
•Restaurant operates for two hours for lunch
•The capacity is 80 customer parties per hour
•A simple way to analyze the situation is to calculate how the 
system looks at the end of each 15-minute interval
•The key is to look at the cumulative numbers
•The difference between cumulative arrivals and cumulative departures 
gives the number of customer parties in the restaurant
•Because there are only 40 tables, when the cumulative 
difference through is greater than 40, a waiting line forms
•Cycle time for the entire restaurant is 45 seconds per customer party at this time

Document 110: Copyright ©2017 McGraw -Hill Education. All rights reserved.Example 11.3: Solution Approach
•Utilization
•The restaurant can accommodate 160 people at a time
•It might be more convenient to measure the capacity in terms of 
customer parties because this is how the capacity will be used
•If the average customer party is 2.5 individuals, then the average seat 
utilization is 62.5 percent when the restaurant is operating at capacity
•Cycle time
•When operating at capacity, 0.75 minute
•30 minutes/40 tables
•On average, a table would become available every 0.75 minute or 
45 seconds
•Capacity
•The restaurant could handle 80 customer parties per hour
•60 minutes/0.75 minute/party

input.speaker: user
input.text: What is the difference between additive and multiplicative seasonal variation in time series decomposition?

targets.text: In time series decomposition, additive seasonal variation is when the forecast including trend and seasonal equals Trend plus Seasonal. Multiplicative seasonal variation is when the forecast including trend and seasonal equals Trend times Seasonal factor.

input.speaker: user
input.text: What is the strategy a firm would use to reduce risk in the face of high levels of supply uncertainty?

targets.text: The strategy is not specified in the provided context.

input.speaker: user
input.text: What is the definition of Takt Time in operations management?

targets.text: Takt Time is the pace of processing to match the pace of customer need. It is the rate for completing work based on customer need. Specifically, Takt time is the effective working time per shift divided by the customer requirement per shift.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Who holds the copyright for the material on outsourcing benefits?

input.speaker: user
input.text: What are the five ways an ERP system streamlines hotel and resort operations?

targets.text: The five ways an ERP system streamlines hotel and resort operations are: Room booking system, Guest management, Front-desk efficiency, Inventory management, and Housekeeping, laundry, and maintenance.

input.speaker: user
input.text: What are some of the benefits of using eKanban systems?

targets.text: eKanban systems reduce inventory which can lead to significant cost savings; they shorten lead times, purchase order cycles and more. They also improve communication across the plant floor by providing instantaneous demand signals across the organization and extended supply chain. These signals are visible and can be tracked by all, including suppliers who have a portal into the system that empowers them to replenish items based on the parameters set.

input.speaker: user
input.text: What is the Bullwhip Effect in the context of supply chain management?

targets.text: The Bullwhip Effect is a phenomenon of variability magnification as we move from the customer to the producer in the supply chain. A slight change in consumer sales ripples backward as magnified oscillations upstream, like the result of a flick of a bullwhip handle.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Can you identify and categorize the following systems as either predominantly push or pull: a copy/printing shop, a vending machine, a 'Pure' MRP system, booking a Driver's or Learner's license on NATIS, a supermarket with goods on shelves, a grillhouse/steakhouse restaurant, and Greyhound Buses at Parkstation?

targets.text: Some examples of systems that could be categorized as either push or pull include a copy/printing shop, a vending machine, a 'Pure' MRP system, booking a Driver's or Learner's license on NATIS, goods on supermarket shelves, a Grillhouse/Steakhouse restaurant, and Greyhound Buses at Parkstation.

input.text: According to the principles outlined by Heizer and Render in their work on Operations Management, what are the fundamental elements that should be considered?

targets.text: The key principles of Operations Management according to Heizer and Render are communication, credibility, security, understanding/knowing the customer, and tangibles.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Could you enumerate the seven principles that guide quality management according to the ISO9000 standard?

targets.text: 1. Customer focus, 2. Leadership, 3. Involvement of people, 4. Process approach, 5. Continual improvement, 6. Factual approach to decision making, 7. Mutually beneficial supplier relationships.

input.speaker: user
input.text: In the realm of operations management, how would you describe the term 'Bottleneck' and its impact on the overall process capacity?

targets.text: Bottleneck is a stage that limits the capacity of the process.

input.speaker: user
input.text: What is the term for a strategy designed to fulfill present requirements without jeopardizing the ability of future generations to meet their own needs, considering a context of dependent demand in a production environment?

targets.text: This refers to a sustainable strategy.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Considering the material 'A Framework for Structuring Supplier Relationships' is part of the 2017 Lean Production lecture notes, who would be the copyright holder for this specific content?

targets.text: The copyright for the 'A Framework for Structuring Supplier Relationships' material is held by McGraw -Hill Education.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Considering the impact of demand information and inventory status on the release of work, could you elaborate on the key differences between a Pull and Push-based system in the context of inventory management?

targets.text: The big difference between a Pull and Push-based system is that a Kanban system 'pulls' inventory and work through the system based upon ACTUAL customer Demand.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Considering the characteristics of a typical organization that transforms inputs into outputs, what are the benefits of implementing CONWIP over a pure push system?

targets.text: CONWIP has the following advantages over a pure push system: The WIP level is directly observable, while the release rate in a push system must be set with respect to (unobservable) capacity. It requires less WIP on average to attain the same throughput. It facilitates working ahead of a schedule when favorable circumstances permit it.

input.speaker: user
input.text: Considering the context of manufacturing environments that are subject to frequent changes in market conditions, could you elaborate on the primary distinctions between Push and Pull-based systems?

targets.text: Push-based systems start with a plan that is pushed through the system, assuming that everything remains constant. This plan often becomes obsolete before it is executed as it cannot easily accommodate changes in market conditions or adjust to variations inherent in manufacturing environments. On the other hand, Pull-based systems are driven from a high-level perspective that focuses on capacity and material planning based on actual customer demand. These systems are designed to be agile enough to respond quickly to changes in demand.

input.speaker: user
input.text: In the context of operations management as discussed in the 7th edition of Operations Management by Nigel Slack, Alistair Brandon-James, and Robert Johnston, what is the significance of overlapping?

targets.text: Overlapping is a method that processes part of the lot on the work center performing the second operation, while the rest of the lot is still in the work center in the first operation. Overlapping reduces lead time in a way similar to parallel processing.

input.speaker: user

targets.text: The Quality Gurus Compared

input.speaker: user
input.text: In the context of the copyrighted material from McGraw-Hill Education, what are the five main process activities in operations and supply chain management?

targets.text: The five main process activities are Planning, Sourcing, Making, Delivering, and Returning.

input.speaker: user
input.text: As an engineering student studying operations management, I am trying to formulate questions from my lecture notes on supply chain uncertainty. Can you tell me what the topic of the content in the provided excerpts from McGraw-Hill Education is?

targets.text: The topic of the content in the provided excerpts from McGraw-Hill Education is Supply Chain Uncertainty and Increasing Variability of Orders Up the Supply Chain.

input.speaker: user
input.text: As a manufacturing engineer preparing for a presentation on contrasting push and pull production systems, specifically with a focus on Kanban systems, could you clarify what the primary difference is between Push-based and Pull-based systems in production environments?

targets.text: Push-based systems are front-loaded in planning and rigid in execution, while Pull-based systems focus on the execution of the customer order and are designed to be agile enough to respond quickly to changes in demand.

input.speaker: user
input.text: As a student revising for an operations management exam, I'm trying to identify the top five ERP software vendors from my lecture notes. Can you tell me what information is missing in the text?

targets.text: The text is missing the names of the Top 5 ERP software vendors.

input.speaker: user
input.text: As a university student studying operations management, I'm trying to understand the benefits of eKanban systems in supply chain management. Could you explain how these systems impact inventory reductions, lead times, and purchase order cycles?

targets.text: eKanban systems offer several benefits in supply chain management. They reduce inventory, leading to significant cost savings; they shorten lead times, purchase order cycles and more. They also elevate the level of communication across the plant floor by providing instantaneous demand signals across the organization and extended supply chain. These signals are visible and can be tracked by all, ensuring everyone is on the same page. eKanban systems also build trust among suppliers by making communication fluid and transparent. This can transform interactions with suppliers into more positive and collaborative relationships.

input.speaker: user

targets.text: The assumptions of the CONWIP model are: 1. Single routing, 2. WIP measured in units.

input.speaker: user

targets.text: 1. Coordinating the relationships between mutually supportive but separate organizations. 2. Optimizing global supplier, production, and distribution networks. 3. Managing customer touch points. 4. Raising senior management awareness of OSCM as a significant competitive weapon. 5. Sustainability and the triple bottom line.

input.speaker: user
input.text: As a student studying for my operations management exam on MRP II systems, I'm trying to generate potential questions. Can you tell me what the main feature of a Closed-loop MRP system is?

targets.text: A Closed-loop MRP system provides feedback to the capacity plan, master production schedule, and production plan so planning can be kept valid at all times.

input.speaker: user
input.text: As an engineering student trying to understand my operations management lecture notes, could you explain to me what Little’s Law is in the context of production process mapping?

targets.text: Little’s Law states that there is a long-term relationship among inventory, throughput, and flow time. It is expressed as Inventory = Throughput rate x Flow time.

input.speaker: user
input.text: As a student studying operations and supply chain management, I'm trying to understand how forecasting affects management decisions in different functions like finance, marketing, and production. Could you tell me what the different types of forecasts used in this field are?

targets.text: Decisions about overall directions require strategic forecasts and tactical forecasts are used to guide day-to-day decisions.

input.speaker: user
input.text: What are some of the major concepts that define the OSCM field and what does the business strategy in this field include?

targets.text: The major concepts that define the OSCM field include manufacturing strategy paradigm, lean manufacturing, JIT, TQC, service quality and productivity, total quality management and quality certification, business process reengineering, six sigma quality, supply chain management, electronic commerce, sustainability and the triple bottom line. The business strategy in this field includes social, economic and environmental criteria.

input.speaker: user
input.text: What is the distinction between manual and electronic Kanban systems, and what is the main difference between a Pull and Push-based system in manufacturing?

targets.text: In a manual Kanban system, there are physical Kanban Cards for each unit of inventory that are located in item bins, shelves, palettes, etc. The Card indicates a replenishment signal for that item. Electronic Kanban or eKanban software systems are digital versions of these systems. The big difference between a Pull and Push-based system, is that a Kanban system “pulls” inventory and work through the system based upon ACTUAL customer Demand.

input.speaker: user
input.text: What does Goldratt's Rule 6 of Production Scheduling state and how does it differ from the utilization and activation of a resource according to Goldratt's Rule 3?

targets.text: Goldratt's Rule 6 of Production Scheduling states that bottlenecks govern both throughput and inventory in the system, which is different from Rule 3 that states utilization and activation of a resource are not the same.

evaluations.model_response: The difference between additive and multiplicative seasonal variation in time series decomposition is in how the seasonal component interacts with the trend component. In additive seasonal variation, the forecast including trend and seasonal components is expressed as the sum: Trend + Seasonal. The five ways an ERP system streamlines hotel and resort operations are:

1. Room booking system
2. Guest management

Some benefits of using eKanban systems include:

1. Real-time tracking of supermarket and kanban status.
2. Instantaneous adjustments based on demand.
3. Enhanced communication across the supplier network.
4. Right-sized inventory through automated K-Loop™ sizing.
5. A closed-loop process for identifying and addressing problems.
6. Reduced administrative burden, allowing focus on strategic tasks.
7. Shorter lead times and improved on-time performance.
8. Functionality in multi-plant, multi-site, multi-distributed environments.
9. Integration with existing MRP/ERP systems.
10. Access to reporting tools and analytics for decision-making.
11. Support for continuous improvement efforts.
12. Reduction in administrative costs related to the replenishment loop.
13. Elimination of the supply chain bullwhip effect.

The Bullwhip Effect in supply chain management is the phenomenon where variability magnifies as it moves from the customer to the producer. A slight change in consumer sales can cause increasingly larger oscillations in demand upstream in the supply chain, similar to the effect of flicking a bullwhip handle.

The pair of tools used by Operations Management professionals to mitigate system nervousness are Time Fences and Pegging. Time fences designate a segment of the master schedule as "not to be rescheduled," thereby reducing unnecessary changes. Pegging involves tracing upward in the Bill of Materials (BOM) from the component to the parent item, allowing production planners to determine the cause for a requirement and assess the necessity of a schedule change.

Based on the provided context, the systems can be categorized as follows:

- **Copy/printing shop:** Predominantly pull (service is often made-to-order).
- **Vending machine:** Predominantly push (items are stocked in anticipation of demand).
- **'Pure' MRP system:** Predominantly push (planned production based on forecasts).
- **Booking a Driver's or Learner's license on NATIS:** Predominantly pull (service is scheduled based on individual requests).
- **Supermarket with goods on shelves:** Predominantly push (goods are stocked in anticipation of customer purchase).
- **Grillhouse/steakhouse restaurant:** Generally pull (meals are prepared to order).
- **Greyhound Buses at Parkstation:** Predominantly push (bus schedules are set in advance, assuming demand).

These categorizations are based on the typical characteristics of push and pull systems as described in the context.

The seven principles that guide quality management according to the ISO9000 standard are:

1. Customer focus
2. Leadership
3. Involvement of people
4. Process approach
5. Continual improvement
6. Factual approach to decision making
7. Mutually beneficial supplier relationships

A bottleneck in operations management is a point in the production process where the capacity is less than the demand placed on a resource. This creates a constraint that limits the overall process capacity. The impact of a bottleneck is significant as it restricts the flow of production, leading to potential delays and reduced throughput. To increase throughput, it is essential to identify and address the bottleneck, as saving time on a bottleneck resource is the only way to enhance the overall production capacity.
The term for a strategy designed to fulfill present requirements without jeopardizing the ability of future generations to meet their own needs is a "sustainable strategy."
The copyright holder for the material 'A Framework for Structuring Supplier Relationships' is McGraw-Hill Education.

In a Pull-based system, work releases are authorized based on the current system status, focusing on actual customer demand and inventory consumption. This approach inherently controls the work-in-progress (WIP) level and observes throughput, allowing for agile responses to changes in demand. In contrast, a Push-based system schedules work releases based on forecasted demand and predetermined schedules. It is inherently driven by due dates and controls the release rate while observing the WIP level. Consequently, the Pull system is more adaptive and responsive to real-time changes, whereas the Push system is more rigid and dependent on forecasts.

CONWIP has several advantages over a pure push system for organizations that transform inputs into outputs:

1. **Directly Observable WIP Level**: Unlike a push system where the release rate must be set based on unobservable capacity, CONWIP allows for direct observation of WIP levels.

2. **Reduced Average WIP**: It requires less work-in-progress to achieve the same throughput, minimizing inventory costs.

3. **Ability to Work Ahead**: It facilitates working ahead of schedule under favorable circumstances, enhancing flexibility.

4. **WIP Cap Establishment**: As a pull system, CONWIP establishes a WIP cap, preventing unnecessary WIP production and improving throughput efficiency.

These benefits lead to cost reductions, improved quality, better customer service, and increased flexibility.

In manufacturing environments subject to frequent changes in market conditions, the primary distinctions between Push and Pull-based systems lie in their planning and execution approaches. Push-based systems, often using MRP/ERP, develop a plan that is pushed through the system based on assumptions of constant conditions, available capacity, and inventory. This approach tends to be rigid and can become obsolete when market conditions change. In contrast, Pull-based systems, such as Kanban, focus on executing customer orders and are designed to be agile. They adapt to actual customer demand, emphasizing capacity and material planning to quickly respond to changes, making them more suitable for dynamic environments.

In the context of operations management as discussed in the 7th edition of Operations Management by Nigel Slack, Alistair Brandon-James, and Robert Johnston, overlapping is significant because it reduces lead time by allowing part of a lot to be processed on the second operation's work center while the rest is still being processed in the first operation. This is similar to parallel processing and helps in improving efficiency.

The topic of the content in the provided excerpts from McGraw-Hill Education is supply chain uncertainty and related concepts. This includes strategies to cope with supply uncertainty, the flow of material in a supply chain, cost estimation including procurement and disposal, and supply chain categorization based on demand and supply uncertainty (efficient, risk-hedging, responsive, and agile supply chains). Additionally, it discusses the bullwhip effect and specific aspects such as sourcing, inventory management, and product life cycles.

The primary difference between Push-based and Pull-based systems in production environments is their approach to planning and execution. Push-based systems are planned and executed based on forecasts and schedules, often using MRP or ERP systems, making them rigid and less adaptable to changes. They assume constant conditions and resources, which can lead to obsolescence if market conditions change. In contrast, Pull-based systems, such as Kanban, are driven by actual customer demand, focusing on execution and being agile enough to quickly respond to changes. Pull systems emphasize flow and control, aiming for efficiency and adaptability, as seen in the Toyota Production System and Lean Manufacturing.

eKanban systems in supply chain management provide several benefits, particularly impacting inventory reductions, lead times, and purchase order cycles. These systems help reduce inventory levels, leading to significant cost savings by ensuring the right amount of inventory is maintained through real-time tracking and demand adjustments. They shorten lead times by enabling faster communication and more efficient processes across the supply chain. Additionally, eKanban systems streamline purchase order cycles by automating and optimizing the replenishment process, allowing for quicker response times and fewer administrative burdens. Overall, they enhance supply chain efficiency and responsiveness.
The assumptions of the CONWIP model are that it involves a single routing and measures work-in-progress (WIP) in units.

The main feature of a Closed-loop MRP system is that it provides feedback to the capacity plan, master production schedule, and production plan to ensure that planning remains valid at all times.

Little’s Law is a mathematical formula used in operations management that captures the relationship between the amount of inventory within a process, the throughput rate (the rate at which items are produced), and the flow time (the time it takes for an item to pass through the process). In the context of production process mapping, Little's Law can be expressed as:

\[ \text{Inventory} = \text{Throughput Rate} \times \text{Flow Time} \]

This relationship helps in understanding how changes in one of these variables affect the others and is fundamental in analyzing and optimizing production processes.

In operations and supply chain management, forecasting is crucial for making informed management decisions across various functions. There are four basic types of forecasts used in this field:

1. **Qualitative Forecasts**: These rely on expert judgment and opinions rather than numerical data.
2. **Time Series Analysis**: This method uses historical data to predict future demand, assuming that past patterns will continue.
3. **Causal Relationships**: This approach identifies and utilizes relationships between variables to forecast future trends.
4. **Simulation**: This involves creating models to simulate various scenarios and predict future outcomes.

Each type of forecast plays a role in functions such as finance, marketing, and production by helping to budget, plan new products, select suppliers, and manage inventory and staffing.
The assumptions for CONWIP are: 1) Single routing and 2) WIP (Work in Process) is measured in units. In terms of modeling, CONWIP looks like a closed queueing network.

The duration for a unit to travel through the process from start to finish is referred to as Throughput Time. The four basic work measurement techniques are:

1. Time study
2. Work sampling
3. Predetermined motion-time data system
4. Elemental data

The major concepts that define the Operations and Supply Chain Management (OSCM) field include the manufacturing strategy paradigm, lean manufacturing, just-in-time (JIT) and total quality control (TQC), service quality and productivity, total quality management and quality certification, business process reengineering, six sigma quality, supply chain management, electronic commerce, and sustainability with the triple bottom line. The business strategy in this field includes social, economic, and environmental criteria.

Manual Kanban systems use physical Kanban cards for each unit of inventory, acting as replenishment signals located in item bins, shelves, pallets, etc. Electronic Kanban, or eKanban systems, are software-based and automate these processes. The main difference between a Pull and Push-based system is that a Kanban system "pulls" inventory and work through the system based on actual customer demand, whereas a Push system schedules production based on forecasts.

Goldratt's Rule 6 of Production Scheduling states that bottlenecks govern both throughput and inventory in the system. This means that the performance of bottlenecks directly affects the overall output and the amount of inventory held in the production system.

Goldratt's Rule 3, on the other hand, states that utilization and activation of a resource are not the same. This means that just because a resource is being used (activation) does not mean it is being used effectively towards productive output (utilization).

The difference lies in that Rule 6 focuses on the impact of bottlenecks on the entire system's efficiency, while Rule 3 distinguishes between merely using a resource and using it effectively to contribute to the system’s productivity.

The formula for calculating the total average value of inventory is the sum of the value of raw materials, work-in-process, and finished goods inventory. Little’s Law relates to production process mapping by establishing a long-term relationship among inventory, throughput, and flow time, expressed as: Inventory = Throughput rate x Flow time.
